title: Ligusticum scoticum
text:
Ligusticum scoticum, known as Scots lovage, or Scottish licorice-root, is a <a href="perennial">perennial</a> <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the <a href="celery">celery</a> family <a href="Apiaceae">Apiaceae</a> (previously Umbelliferae) found near the coasts of northern Europe and north-eastern North America. It grows up to tall and is found in rock crevices and cliff-top grassland. It is closely related to, and possibly conspecific with, "<a href="Ligusticum%20hultenii">Ligusticum hultenii</a>" from the coast of the northern Pacific Ocean. The plant is edible and contains the compound <a href="sotolon">sotolon</a>, which is also present in <a href="fenugreek">fenugreek</a>. The leaves have a flavour similar to <a href="parsley">parsley</a> or celery, while the seeds taste similar to <a href="fenugreek">fenugreek</a> or <a href="cumin">cumin</a>.
Description.
"Ligusticum scoticum" is a <a href="herbaceous%20plant">herbaceous</a> <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial plant</a> which typically grows tall. It has triangular, twice-<a href="Glossary%20of%20leaf%20morphology">ternate</a> leaves, long, with each lobe long. The edges of the leaves may be toothed, lobed or serrated, and are typically either a paler green or magenta. The <a href="Plant%20stem">stem</a> branches infrequently, and bears 2–5 <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a>s, each of which is a compound <a href="umbel">umbel</a> in diameter. There are typically 8–12 rays in both the primary and secondary umbels. Each individual flower is around in diameter and greenish-white in colour. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> are long, with five prominent ridges on each <a href="carpel">carpel</a>.
"Ligusticum scoticum" tastes and smells like <a href="parsley">parsley</a> or <a href="celery">celery</a>.
Distribution.
"Ligusticum scoticum" is primarily an <a href="Arctic">Arctic</a> plant, with a <a href="disjunct%20distribution">disjunct range</a> extending from <a href="northern%20Norway">northern Norway</a> to the more northerly shores of the <a href="British%20Isles">British Isles</a>, and from western <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a> to <a href="New%20England">New England</a>. A related species, "<a href="Ligusticum%20hultenii">Ligusticum hultenii</a>", which was described by <a href="Merritt%20Lyndon%20Fernald">Merritt Lyndon Fernald</a> in 1930 and may be better treated as a <a href="subspecies">subspecies</a> of "L. scoticum", occurs around the northern Pacific Ocean, from <a href="Japan">Japan</a> to <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a>. The southernmost occurrence of "L. scoticum" is at <a href="Ballyhalbert">Ballyhalbert</a> in <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>.
Ecology.
Within the British Isles, "Ligusticum scoticum" is only found on coasts where the mean July <a href="temperature">temperature</a> is below , and this bound is likely also to apply in other parts of the species' range. Towards the southern end of its range, the plant performs poorly on south-facing sites. It grows in fissures in rocks, where it may be the only vascular plant, and also in cliff-top grassland communities dominated by "<a href="Festuca%20rubra">Festuca rubra</a>" and "<a href="Plantago%20maritima">Plantago maritima</a>".
"Ligusticum scoticum" cannot tolerate <a href="grazing">grazing</a>, and is harmed by the actions of nesting <a href="seabird">seabird</a>s; it is therefore rarely found on bird cliffs, or where grazing sheep and rabbits are found. It is, however, tolerant of <a href="salt%20spray">salt spray</a>, and its growth has been shown to improve when given dilute <a href="sea%20water">sea water</a>. The leaves of "L. scoticum" are frost-tolerant, and die back each winter, but regrow very rapidly the following spring. In the British Isles, <a href="flowering">flowering</a> occurs from June to August, and the seeds are ripe in October or November; the timing is expected to be later at higher latitudes. The flowers of "L. scoticum" are visited by generalist <a href="pollinator">pollinator</a>s, mostly <a href="fly">flies</a>.
Taxonomy.
"Ligusticum scoticum" was first described by <a href="Carl%20Linnaeus">Carl Linnaeus</a> in his 1753 work '. Linnaeus originally used the <a href="specific%20name%20%28botany%29">epithet</a> ', and this is used by many authors in North America; in Europe, the amended spelling "" is used.
Uses.
The plant was formerly widely eaten in western Britain, both for nutrition and to combat <a href="scurvy">scurvy</a>. The leaves and stalks are edible before the flowers appear, and contain <a href="vitamin%20A">vitamin A</a> and <a href="Vitamin%20C">C</a>. They can be consumed raw or cooked like celery. Additionally, the young shoots can be candied.
